titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Cornell family land deeds 1974.053
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:17:34 +0000.

did.abstract: Deeds documenting transactions among members of the Cornell family for land along the East River in Brooklyn, dating from 1784 to 1792. Isaac Cornell (d. 1824) purchased a large tract of land from the heirs of Jacob Sebring in 1784. A year later, he sold one-third of the shares to his brothers, John (1753-1820) and William (ca. 1755-1820). In 1787, Isaac sold William an additional portion, and in 1792 John purchased all tracts belonging to his brothers.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Ronald Elliot Curtis, 1940. Formally accessioned in 1974.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Cornell family land deeds, 1974.053, Box and Folder number; Center for Brooklyn History, Brooklyn Public Library.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: These deeds are fragile and most are folded. CBH staff must supervise use.
